developmental_risk_block.text: Developmental risk is flagged due to limited adolescent data and uncertain long-term effects. Endocrine, growth, neurodevelopmental, and metabolic setpoints may be sensitive to perturbation. This section is descriptive only; uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged.

interaction_summary.text: Interactions here are category flags — they’re meant to help you ask better questions and avoid obvious conflicts. They are not a dosing guide.
interaction_summary.title: Interaction summary

interaction_summary.text: If you’re on cardiovascular, anticoagulant/antiplatelet, serotonergic, or immunomodulating meds/supplements, treat uncertainty as a reason to slow down and verify with a clinician.

current_outlook_bullets: studied are summarized here in a conservative, evidence-bounded way
common biohacker curiosity due to community reports
interest in mechanisms suggested by early evidence
exploration in wellness communities despite evidence limits

evidence.title: A 16-amino-acid peptide named MOTS-c regulates insulin sensitivity and metabolic homeostasis
MOTS-c is an exercise-induced mitochondrial-encoded regulator of age-dependent physical decline and muscle homeostasis
evidence.notes: Animal study; does not establish human efficacy.

evidence.title: Effect of aerobic and resistance exercise on the mitochondrial-derived peptide MOTS-c (human observational biomarker context)
evidence.notes: Human observational/biomarker context; not proof of clinical benefit.

evidence.title: MOTS-c: A promising mitochondrial-derived peptide (review)
evidence.notes: Review synthesis; use for uncertainty boundaries.

evidence.title: MOTS-c, the Most Recent Mitochondrial Derived Peptide (review)
evidence.notes: Review synthesis; not proof of efficacy.

changelog.detail: Generated from queue ingestion (Phase 6). Requires human-authored, evidence-bounded content.

changelog.summary: Added conservative evidence set and linked overview evidence_refs (no instructions).
changelog.detail: Inserted primary discovery paper, animal study, human observational context, and two reviews. Linked overview blocks to evidence IDs. No dosing/protocol language added.

practical.bottom_line: MOTS-c is discussed for metabolic health and exercise performance themes, often framed as “mitochondrial support.” Human evidence is limited, so expectations should be conservative.
benefits: exercise tolerance and recovery discussions (mixed, often overstated)
sometimes discussed for insulin sensitivity themes (uncertain outcomes)
side_effects_serious: severe allergic reaction symptoms (hives, facial swelling, trouble breathing)
chest pain, fainting, or severe shortness of breath
who_should_be_cautious: people with diabetes or unstable blood sugar control
adolescents (limited human evidence and endocrine/metabolic uncertainty)
